The new velocity v_f after the collision can be calculated using the conservation of momentum. The initial momentum p_i = mv_i and the final momentum p_f = mv_f.
Since the post-collision velocity v_f is the same as the pre-collision velocity v_i, we have v_f = v_i.
Using the conservation of momentum, m * v_i = m * v_f, we find v_f = v_i.
Since the post-collision velocity v_f is the same as the pre-collision velocity v_i, the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is v_f/v_i = 1.

The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is the same as the ratio of the gravitational force to the air resistance, which is 1/λ.
Since the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is 1, the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is 1/λ.
